posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked:
NOMAD CAD Release 2025

Team 6995 presents the CAD for our 2025 Robot: Mariana!

We wanted to highlight a few changes we made in preparation for Worlds:

New Intake
- Even though we had success intaking at Orange County, as the defensive meta evolved, we began struggling under heavy defense. After 30 iterations of trying different wheels and minor customizations, we landed on our final hand. Here’s our final hand design: [Link](#)

New Climb
- During the season, our hook climber struggled to hold itself up for more than 3 seconds. After seeing many top teams use a wheeled climber, we switched back to our hook-based version. This new design should reduce our climb time from 15 seconds to 5-7 seconds. [Link](#)

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked: This robot is one of the cleanest ones I've seen this year. Congrats on an amazing season! Hoping to see you all make Einstein!

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: This is such a cool robot, although there's a bad pun, and nocad is involved.

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: The iteration throughout the season looks great! Good luck in your division, twin.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: I see you're going for the motorized wheel cage grabber. Instead of having both poles, you've gone with one. How's that working out? Is there a particular reason for choosing a single pole over two?

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: The single pole grabber was something we built for our Week 3 event but didn’t end up using. At the time it stucked perpendicular to the elevator and we found that it had trouble pulling in the pipe and did not pull the eye bolt down enough to get us off the ground. Instead of building a 2-pipe climber, we angled our existing one up 12 degrees, which let it be outside the bumper for grabbing and pulled the eye bolt an extra inch plus lower. It works well now.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked: We chose the single pole design over the dual pole since our testing showed that hitting the cage at any angle would likely result in a corner being grabbed. This reduces the time needed to align the driver.

posts.name: waialua3:59
posts.cooked: We have something similar, and I can tell you that a motorized set of wheels looking for a single pole works much easier and faster to lock into the cage. With the cage swinging, it’s still just as quick.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked: This concept may end up on our off-season bot! Thanks for the insight.

posts.name: Gabriel McMahon
posts.cooked: Love the design! Your brainpan design is quite distinctive compared to others I've encountered, and I'm curious how accessible it is when rushing. Additionally, I noticed several 3D prints near your pivot point, wondering what filament you're using, and I wanted to check if you've encountered any issues with parts breaking during printing.

posts.name: sol stirling
posts.cooked: We flip the robot sideways, remove the polycarbonate cover from the bottom by unscrewing a few bolts and attaching Riv nuts, which takes about 30 seconds. This allows us to work on whatever repairs or modifications we need. Our 3D-printed parts for the pivot mechanism use PLA filament (as I recall) and function effectively without any issues, as they serve purely as spacers or axial constraints rather than bearing any load.

posts.name: Bpk9p4
posts.cooked: What's a very cool robot? I was looking at your CAD and didn't really get how your friction brake works. Could you explain that a bit more?
It was awesome watching this bot cook. How do you deal with backlash when a lot of the gear reductions on the pivot come from gear to gear interaction?

All the gears on the pivot mech are from REV, having a tighter hex bore than other hex gears. During assembly, we shimmed and tightened all the gears on the hex shaft. Additionally, each Kraken pinion was green-loticated to its spline-x shaft. Routine checking and tightening of the #35 chain ensured minimal backlash on our arm during competitions.

posts.cooked: Congratulations on your incredible run in your division and on Einstein, you were a very valuable member on the Daly alliance!

posts.name: Eli Uva
posts.cooked: It was awesome seeing you guys win your division on Daly! You guys built and amazing robot and an incredible team.

posts.name: Gabriel McMahon
posts.cooked: Thank you! If there was one thing you would have designed differently from the start or still want to tweak, what would it be?

posts.name: meer
posts.cooked: Is there a weight estimate of the elevator and endevator alone?
Cad so clean it could be used in the medical industry
